intro: Urtica pedunculata, commonly known as the stinging nettle, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Urticaceae family. It is characterized by its opposite, heart-shaped leaves covered in fine, hollow hairs that release an irritant when touched. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically wind-pollinated. Urtica pedunculata is native to various regions in Europe, Asia, and North America, often growing in moist, disturbed soils. It has historical uses in traditional medicine and as a source of fiber.
